name: lume
author: rxi
description: A collection of functions for Lua, geared towards game development.

api.name: clamp
api.description: Returns the number `x` clamped between the numbers `min` and `max`

api.name: round
api.description: Rounds `x` to the nearest integer; rounds away from zero if we're midway between two integers. If `increment` is set then the number is rounded to the nearest increment.

api.name: sign
api.description: Returns `1` if `x` is 0 or above, returns `-1` when `x` is negative.

api.name: lerp
api.description: Returns the linearly interpolated number between `a` and `b`, `amount` should be in the range of 0 - 1; if `amount` is outside of this range it is clamped.

api.name: smooth
api.description: Similar to `lume.lerp()` but uses cubic interpolation instead of linear interpolation.

api.name: pingpong
api.description: Ping-pongs the number `x` between 0 and 1.

api.name: distance
api.description: Returns the distance between the two points. If `squared` is true then the squared distance is returned -- this is faster to calculate and can still be used when comparing distances.

api.name: angle
api.description: Returns the angle between the two points.

api.name: vector
api.description: Given an `angle` and `magnitude`, returns a vector.

api.name: random
api.description: Returns a random number between `a` and `b`. If only `a` is supplied a number between `0` and `a` is returned. If no arguments are supplied a random number between `0` and `1` is returned.

api.name: randomchoice
api.description: Returns a random value from array `t`. If the array is empty an error is raised.
api.example: lume.randomchoice({true, false}) -- Returns either true or false

api.name: weightedchoice
api.description: Takes the argument table `t` where the keys are the possible choices and the value is the choice's weight. A weight should be 0 or above, the larger the number the higher the probability of that choice being picked. If the table is empty, a weight is below zero or all the weights are 0 then an error is raised.
api.example:
lume.weightedchoice({ ["cat"] = 10, ["dog"] = 5, ["frog"] = 0 })
-- Returns either "cat" or "dog" with "cat" being twice as likely to be chosen.

api.name: isarray
api.description: Returns `true` if `x` is an array -- the value is assumed to be an array if it is a table which contains a value at the index `1`. This function is used internally and can be overridden if you wish to use a different method to detect arrays.

api.name: push
api.description: Pushes all the given values to the end of the table `t` and returns the pushed values. Nil values are ignored.

api.name: remove
api.description: Removes the first instance of the value `x` if it exists in the table `t`. Returns `x`.

api.name: clear
api.description: Nils all the values in the table `t`, this renders the table empty. Returns `t`.

api.name: extend
api.description: Copies all the fields from the source tables to the table `t` and returns `t`. If a key exists in multiple tables the right-most table's value is used.
api.example:
local t = { a = 1, b = 2 }
lume.extend(t, { b = 4, c = 6 }) -- `t` becomes { a = 1, b = 4, c = 6 }

api.name: shuffle
api.description: Returns a shuffled copy of the array `t`.

api.name: sort
api.description: Returns a copy of the array `t` with all its items sorted. If `comp` is a function it will be used to compare the items when sorting. If `comp` is a string it will be used as the key to sort the items by.

api.name: array
api.description: Iterates the supplied iterator and returns an array filled with the values.

api.name: each
api.description: Iterates the table `t` and calls the function `fn` on each value followed by the supplied additional arguments; if `fn` is a string the method of that name is called for each value. The function returns `t` unmodified.
api.example:
lume.each({1, 2, 3}, print) -- Prints "1", "2", "3" on separate lines
lume.each({a, b, c}, "move", 10, 20) -- Does x:move(10, 20) on each value

api.name: map
api.description: Applies the function `fn` to each value in table `t` and returns a new table with the resulting values.
api.example: lume.map({1, 2, 3}, function(x) return x * 2 end) -- Returns {2, 4, 6}

api.name: all
api.description: Returns true if all the values in `t` table are true. If a `fn` function is supplied it is called on each value, true is returned if all of the calls to `fn` return true.
api.example: lume.all({1, 2, 1}, function(x) return x == 1 end) -- Returns false

api.name: any
api.description: Returns true if any of the values in `t` table are true. If a `fn` function is supplied it is called on each value, true is returned if any of the calls to `fn` return true.
api.example: lume.any({1, 2, 1}, function(x) return x == 1 end) -- Returns true

api.name: reduce
api.description: Applies `fn` on two arguments cumulative to the items of the array `t`, from left to right, so as to reduce the array to a single value. If a `first` value is specified the accumulator is initialised to this, otherwise the first value in the array is used. If the array is empty and no `first` value is specified an error is raised.
api.example: lume.reduce({1, 2, 3}, function(a, b) return a + b end) -- Returns 6

api.name: unique
api.description: Returns a copy of the `t` array with all the duplicate values removed.

api.name: filter
api.description: Calls `fn` on each value of `t` table. Returns a new table with only the values where `fn` returned true. If `retainkeys` is true the table is not treated as an array and retains its original keys.
api.example: lume.filter({1, 2, 3, 4}, function(x) return x % 2 == 0 end) -- Returns {2, 4}

api.name: reject
api.description: The opposite of `lume.filter()`: Calls `fn` on each value of `t` table; returns a new table with only the values where `fn` returned false. If `retainkeys` is true the table is not treated as an array and retains its original keys.
api.example: lume.reject({1, 2, 3, 4}, function(x) return x % 2 == 0 end) -- Returns {1, 3}

api.name: merge
api.description: Returns a new table with all the given tables merged together. If a key exists in multiple tables the right-most table's value is used.
api.example: lume.merge({a=1, b=2, c=3}, {c=8, d=9}) -- Returns {a=1, b=2, c=8, d=9}

api.name: concat
api.description: Returns a new array consisting of all the given arrays concatenated into one.

api.name: find
api.description: Returns the index/key of `value` in `t`. Returns `nil` if that value does not exist in the table.

api.name: match
api.description: Returns the value and key of the value in table `t` which returns true when `fn` is called on it. Returns `nil` if no such value exists.
api.example: lume.match({1, 5, 8, 7}, function(x) return x % 2 == 0 end) -- Returns 8, 3

api.name: count
api.description: Counts the number of values in the table `t`. If a `fn` function is supplied it is called on each value, the number of times it returns true is counted.
api.example:
lume.count({a = 2, b = 3, c = 4, d = 5}) -- Returns 4
lume.count({1, 2, 4, 6}, function(x) return x % 2 == 0 end) -- Returns 3

api.name: slice
api.description: Mimics the behaviour of Lua's `string.sub`, but operates on an array rather than a string. Creates and returns a new array of the given slice.

api.name: first
api.description: Returns the first element of an array or nil if the array is empty. If `n` is specificed an array of the first `n` elements is returned.

api.name: last
api.description: Returns the last element of an array or nil if the array is empty. If `n` is specificed an array of the last `n` elements is returned.

api.name: invert
api.description: Returns a copy of the table where the keys have become the values and the values the keys.

api.name: pick
api.description: Returns a copy of the table filtered to only contain values for the given keys.
api.example: lume.pick({ a = 1, b = 2, c = 3 }, "a", "c") -- Returns { a = 1, c = 3 }

api.name: keys
api.description: Returns an array containing each key of the table.

api.name: clone
api.description: Returns a shallow copy of the table `t`.

api.name: fn
api.description: Creates a wrapper function around function `fn`, automatically inserting the arguments into `fn` which will persist every time the wrapper is called. Any arguments which are passed to the returned function will be inserted after the already existing arguments passed to `fn`.
api.example:
local f = lume.fn(print, "Hello")
f("world") -- Prints "Hello world"

api.name: once
api.description: Returns a wrapper function to `fn` which takes the supplied arguments. The wrapper function will call `fn` on the first call and do nothing on any subsequent calls.
api.example:
local f = lume.once(print, "Hello")
f() -- Prints "Hello"f() -- Does nothing

api.name: memoize
api.description: Returns a wrapper function to `fn` where the results for any given set of arguments are cached. `lume.memoize()` is useful when used on functions with slow-running computations.
api.example: fib = lume.memoize(function(n) return n < 2 and n or fib(n-1) + fib(n-2) end)

api.name: combine
api.description: Creates a wrapper function which calls each supplied argument in the order they were passed to `lume.combine()`; nil arguments are ignored. The wrapper function passes its own arguments to each of its wrapped functions when it is called.

api.name: call
api.description: Calls the given function with the provided arguments and returns its values. If `fn` is `nil` then no action is performed and the function returns `nil`.

api.name: time
api.description: Inserts the arguments into function `fn` and calls it. Returns the time in seconds the function `fn` took to execute followed by `fn`'s returned values.

api.name: lambda
api.description: Takes a string lambda and returns a function. `str` should be a list of comma-separated parameters, followed by `->`, followed by the expression which will be evaluated and returned.

api.name: serialize
api.description: Serializes the argument `x` into a string which can be loaded again using `lume.deserialize()`. Only booleans, numbers, tables and strings can be serialized. Circular references will result in an error; all nested tables are serialized as unique tables.

api.name: deserialize
api.description: Deserializes a string created by `lume.serialize()` and returns the resulting value. This function should not be run on an untrusted string.

api.name: split
api.description: Returns an array of the words in the string `str`. If `sep` is provided it is used as the delimiter, consecutive delimiters are not grouped together and will delimit empty strings.

api.name: trim
api.description: Trims the whitespace from the start and end of the string `str` and returns the new string. If a `chars` value is set the characters in `chars` are trimmed instead of whitespace.

api.name: wordwrap
api.description: Returns `str` wrapped to `limit` number of characters per line, by default `limit` is `72`. `limit` can also be a function which when passed a string, returns `true` if it is too long for a single line.
api.example:
-- Returns "Hello world
This is a
short string"
lume.wordwrap("Hello world. This is a short string", 14)

api.name: format
api.description: Returns a formatted string. The values of keys in the table `vars` can be inserted into the string by using the form `"{key}"` in `str`; numerical keys can also be used.
api.example:
lume.format("{b} hi {a}", {a = "mark", b = "Oh"}) -- Returns "Oh hi mark"
lume.format("Hello {1}!", {"world"}) -- Returns "Hello world!"

api.name: trace
api.description: Prints the current filename and line number followed by each argument separated by a space.
api.example:
-- Assuming the file is called "example.lua" and the next line is 12:
lume.trace("hello", 1234) -- Prints "example.lua:12: hello 1234"

api.name: dostring
api.description: Executes the lua code inside `str`.

api.name: uuid
api.description: Generates a random UUID string; version 4 as specified in [RFC 4122](http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4122.txt).

api.name: hotswap
api.description: Reloads an already loaded module in place, allowing you to immediately see the effects of code changes without having to restart the program. `modname` should be the same string used when loading the module with require(). In the case of an error the global environment is restored and `nil` plus an error message is returned.
api.example:
lume.hotswap("lume") -- Reloads the lume module
assert(lume.hotswap("inexistant_module")) -- Raises an error

api.name: ripairs
api.description: Performs the same function as `ipairs()` but iterates in reverse; this allows the removal of items from the table during iteration without any items being skipped.
api.example:
-- Prints "3->c", "2->b" and "1->a" on separate lines
for i, v in lume.ripairs({ "a", "b", "c" }) do
  print(i .. "->" .. v)
end

api.name: color
api.description: Takes color string `str` and returns 4 values, one for each color channel (`r`, `g`, `b` and `a`). By default the returned values are between 0 and 1; the values are multiplied by the number `mul` if it is provided.
api.example:
lume.color("#ff0000")               -- Returns 1, 0, 0, 1
lume.color("rgba(255, 0, 255, .5)") -- Returns 1, 0, 1, .5
lume.color("#00ffff", 256)          -- Returns 0, 256, 256, 256
lume.color("rgb(255, 0, 0)", 256)   -- Returns 256, 0, 0, 256

api.name: chain
api.description: Returns a wrapped object which allows chaining of lume functions. The function result() should be called at the end of the chain to return the resulting value.
api.example:
lume.chain({1, 2, 3, 4})
  :filter(function(x) return x % 2 == 0 end)
  :map(function(x) return -x end)
  :result() -- Returns { -2, -4 }

name: batteries
author: 1bardesign
description: batteries fills out lua's sparse standard library a little, and provides implementations of common algorithms and data structures useful for games.

api.name: assert:some
api.description: assert a value is not nil, returns the value

api.name: assert:equal
api.description: assert two values are equal

api.name: assert:not_equal
api.description: assert two values are not equal

api.name: assert:type
api.description: assert a value is of a certain type

api.name: assert:nop
api.description: Replace everything in assert with nop functions that just return their second argument, for near-zero overhead on release

api.name: mathx.wrap
api.description: Wrap v around range [lo, hi]

api.name: mathx.wrap_index
api.description: Wrap i around the indices of t

api.name: mathx.clamp
api.description: Clamp v to range [lo, hi]

api.name: mathx.clamp01
api.description: Clamp v to range [0, 1]

api.name: mathx.round
api.description: Round v to nearest whole, away from zero

api.name: mathx.to_one_in
api.description: Round v to one-in x

api.name: mathx.to_precision
api.description: Round v to a given decimal precision

api.name: mathx.sign
api.description: 0, 1, -1 sign of a scalar

api.name: mathx.lerp
api.description: Linear interpolation between a and b

api.name: mathx.lerp_eps
api.description:
Linear interpolation with a minimum "final step" distance
Useful for making sure dynamic lerps do actually reach their final destination

api.name: mathx.bilerp
api.arguments: a, b, c, d, u, v
api.description: Bilinear interpolation between 4 samples

api.name: mathx.smoothstep
api.description:
Classic smoothstep
(Only "safe" for 0-1 range)

api.name: mathx.smootherstep
api.description:
Classic smootherstep; zero 2nd order derivatives at 0 and 1
(Only safe for 0-1 range)

api.name: mathx.random_sign
api.description: Return a random sign

api.name: mathx.random_lerp
api.description: Return a random value between two numbers (continuous)

api.name: mathx.isnan
api.description: Nan checking

api.name: mathx.tau
api.description: Superior constant handy for expressing things in turns

api.name: mathx.normalise_angle
api.description:
Normalise angle onto the interval [-math.pi, math.pi)
So each angle only has a single value representing it

api.name: mathx.normalize_angle
api.description:
Normalize angle onto the interval [-math.pi, math.pi)
So each angle only has a single value representing it

api.name: mathx.angle_difference
api.description: Get the normalised difference between two angles

api.name: mathx.lerp_angle
api.description: Mathx.lerp equivalent for angles

api.name: mathx.lerp_angle_eps
api.description: Mathx.lerp_eps equivalent for angles

api.name: mathx.rotate
api.description: Rotate a point around the origin by an angle

api.name: mathx.length
api.description: Get the length of a vector from the origin

api.name: mathx.distance
api.description: Get the distance between two points

api.name: stringx.split
api.description: Split a string on a delimiter into an ordered table

api.name: stringx.trim
api.description:
Trim all whitespace off the head and tail of a string
Specifically trims space, tab, newline, and carriage return characters
Ignores form feeds, vertical tabs, and backspaces

api.name: stringx.ltrim
api.description: Trim the start of a string

api.name: stringx.rtrim
api.description: Trim the end of a string

api.name: stringx.deindent
api.description: Remove identation from a string

api.name: stringx.apply_template
api.description:
Apply a template to a string
ie ('hello $name'):format({name = 'tom'}) == 'hello tom'

api.name: stringx.contains
api.description: Check if a given string contains another (without garbage)

api.name: stringx.starts_with
api.description: Check if a given string starts with another (without garbage)

api.name: stringx.ends_with
api.description: Check if a given string ends with another (without garbage)

api.name: functional.identity
api.description: The identity function, returns the value

api.name: functional.foreach
api.description:
Simple sequential iteration, f is called for all elements of t
f can return non-nil to break the loop (and return the value)

api.name: functional.reduce
api.description: Iteratively performs a left to right reduction of t using f, with seed as the initial value

api.name: functional.map
api.description: Maps a sequence {a, b, c} -> {f(a), f(b), f(c)}, automatically drops any nils

api.name: functional.map_inplace
api.description: Maps a sequence inplace, modifying it {a, b, c} -> {f(a), f(b), f(c)}

api.name: functional.filter
api.description: Filters a sequence by returning a table containing items where f(v, i) returns truthy

api.name: functional.filter_inplace
api.description: Filters a sequence in place, modifying it

api.name: functional.remove_if
api.description: Complement of filter, returns a table containing items where f(v) returns falsey

api.name: functional.partition
api.description: Partitions a sequence into two, based on filter criteria, simultaneous filter and remove_if

api.name: functional.group_by
api.description: Returns a table where the elements in t are grouped into sequential tables by the result of f on each element

api.name: functional.zip
api.description: Zips two sequences together into a new table, based on another function

api.name: functional.stitch
api.description: Maps a sequence {a, b, c} -> collapse { f(a), f(b), f(c) }

api.name: functional.cycle
api.description: Maps a sequence {a, b, c} -> { f(a, b), f(b, c), f(c, a) }

api.name: functional.generate
api.description: Generate data into a table, basically a map on numeric values from 1 to count

api.name: functional.generate_2d
api.description: 2d version of generate() but ends up with a 1d table

api.name: functional.any
api.description: True if any element of the table matches f

api.name: functional.none
api.description: True if no element of the table matches f

api.name: functional.all
api.description: True if all elements of the table match f

api.name: functional.count
api.description: Counts the elements of t that match f

api.name: functional.contains
api.description: True if the table contains element e

api.name: functional.sum
api.description: Return the numeric sum of all elements of t

api.name: functional.mean
api.description: Return the numeric mean of all elements of t

api.name: functional.minmax
api.description: Return the minimum and maximum of t in one pass or zero for both if t is empty

api.name: functional.max
api.description: Return the maximum element of t or zero if t is empty

api.name: functional.min
api.description: Return the minimum element of t or zero if t is empty

api.name: functional.find_min
api.description: Return the element of the table that results in the lowest numeric value

api.name: functional.find_max
api.description: Return the element of the table that results in the greatest numeric value

api.name: functional.find_nearest
api.description: Return the element of the table that results in the value nearest to the passed value

api.name: functional.find_match
api.description: Return the first element of the table that results in a true filter

name: step
author: Sheepolution
description: A small immediate mode timer module that makes it easier to have an action execute with a certain interval or after a delay.

api.name: every
api.description: Creates a timer which returns true every `duration` seconds. If `max_duration` is set the duration will be a random float between `duration` and `max_duration` every loop.
api.example:
timer = step.every(3)
if timer:update(dt) then
  print("This will be printed every 3 seconds")
end

api.name: update
api.description: Update the timer with `timer:update(dt)` or by calling your timer (`timer(dt)`) and pass the delta time as argument.
api.example:
if timer(dt) then
  print("This will be printed every 3 seconds.")
end

api.name: after
api.description: Creates a timer which continuously returns true after `duration` seconds. If `max_duration` is set the duration will be a random float between `duration` and `max_duration` every reset.
api.example:
timer = step.after(3)
if timer:update(dt) then
  print("After 3 seconds this will be printed every frame.")
end

api.name: once
api.description: Creates a timer which returns true once after `duration` seconds. If `max_duration` is set the duration will be a random float between `duration` and `max_duration` every reset.
api.example:
timer = step.once(3)
if timer:update(dt) then
  print("After 3 seconds this will be printed once.")
end

api.name: during
api.description: Creates a timer which returns true until after `duration` seconds. If `max_duration` is set the duration will be a random float between `duration` and `max_duration` every reset.
api.example:
timer = step.once(3)
if timer:update(dt) then
  print("This will be printed every frame until 3 seconds have passed.")
end

api.name: reset
api.description: You can always reset your timer with `timer:reset()` or simply calling your timer without arguments.

api.name: set
api.description: Change the time for this timer. Will also reset the timer unless `noreset` is `true`.
api.example:
timer = step.every(5)
timer:set(3) --Now it will loop every 3 seconds instead.

api.name: finish
api.description: Set the timer to the end so that on the next update it will return `true` for a `once` and `every` timer.
api.example:
timer = step.new(4.7)
timer:finish()
if timer(dt) then
  print("On the first frame this will be printed and then again after 4.7 seconds.")
end

name: NLay
author: MikuAuahDark
description: NLay is layouting library inspired by the flexibility of Android's ConstraintLayout.

api.name: inside
api.description: Create new `Inside` object (constraint with padding information), used to construct `Constraint` object later.

api.name: update
api.description: Update the root constraint dimensions.

api.name: max
api.description: Create new constraint whose the size and the position is based on bounding box of the other constraints.
api.example: local maxConstraint = NLay.max(con1, con2, con3, con4)

api.name: line
api.description: Create new guideline constraint.

api.name: Inside:constraint
api.description: Create new `Constraint` object. At least contain 1 horizontal and 1 vertical constraints is required.
api.example: local topRightAlignConstraint = inRoot:constraint(NLay, nil, nil, NLay)

api.name: BaseConstraint:get
api.description: Retrieve the positions and the dimensions of constraint.

api.name: Constraint:into
api.description: This function tells to NOT use the opposite sides of the constraint for constraint at top, left, bottom, and/or right.

api.name: Constraint:margin
api.description: Sets the constraint margin.
api.example:
constraint:margin(10) -- sets margin for all sides
constraint:margin({10, 0, 0, 10}) -- sets margin for top right sides

api.name: Constraint:size
api.description: Sets the constraint width and height.
api.example:
constraint:size(48, 48) -- fixed size
constraint:size(0, 48) -- width is calculated from left and right constraint

api.name: Constraint:bias
api.description: Set the constraint bias.
api.example: constraint:bias(0.5, 0.75) -- places the constraint at horizontal center and 3/4 vertical

api.name: Constraint:forceIn
api.description: **Niche-case function!** Force the "into" flags to be determined by user even if it may result as invalid constraint.

api.name: Constraint:tag
api.description: Tag this constraint with user-specific data.

api.name: Constraint:getTag
api.description: Retrieve tag data previously set from constraint.

name: Runtime Texture Atlas (RTA)
author: EngineerSmith
description: Texture atlas packer and renderer at runtime; no external tools.

api.name: RTA.newFixedSize
api.description: Create a fixed sized texture atlas; for a specific sized image

api.name: RTA.newDynamicSize
api.description: Create a dynamic sized texture atlas; for any sized image

api.name: atlas:useImageData
api.description:
Change mode for the atlas to use imageData instead of love.graphics; useful for headless versions of love.
You cannot change this setting after adding images to the texture atlas!

api.name: atlas:setFilter
api.description: Change filter used for the atlas; this will always override the default filter even if not changed

api.name: atlas:setBakeAsPow2
api.description: Will round the width and height to the nearest power of 2 value. Warning, packing algorithms are not optimized for spacing towards the closest power of 2 and will just pad.

api.name: atlas:setPadding
api.description: Set the padding around each image; this will push the image away from the edge of the atlas.

api.name: atlas:setExtrude
api.description: Set the amount the image is extruded by; this will use the warp mode set for the image. Unless the atlas is in imageData mode then it will use clamp.

api.name: atlas:setSpacing
api.description: Set spacing between each image; does not add spacing between images and the edge of the atlas

api.name: atlas:setMaxSize
api.description: Sets the maximum size for the texture atlas. Default is the current system limits unless in imageData mode then it is 16,384
api.example:
atlas:setMaxSize(1000, 1000)
atlas:setMaxSize(100) -- height becomes system limit
atlas:setMaxSize(nil, 100) -- width becomes system limit

api.name: atlas:add
api.description: Add or replace an image to the atlas. Image can be either image or imageData depending on the mode set for the atlas (default image). ID can be any table index, not just numbers or strings. Use 3rd argument to bake change; recommended only bake when all changes have been made. 4th argument is passed into atlas:bake, useful for specifying sorting algorithm for dynamic atlases

api.name: atlas:remove
api.description: Remove image added to atlas. Use 2rd argument to bake change; recommended only bake when all changes have been made. 3rd argument is passed into atlas:bake, useful for specifying sorting algorithm for dynamic atlases

api.name: atlas:getViewport
api.description: Get viewport for given id; returns position, width and height for it's location on the texture atlas. Useful for getting the location for a mesh's uvs.

api.name: atlas:bake
api.description:
Bake the texture atlas; sortby is only used by dynamic atlases. Options: area, height, width, none
Note, it's recommended to use atlas:hardBake once all changes have been made.

api.name: atlas:hardBake
api.description: Hard bake the atlas; this will bake and remove all internal references to the added images. You won't be able to change the settings of the atlas after this point.

api.name: atlas:draw
api.description: Draw the given id; arguments passed after id is given to love.graphics.draw

api.name: atlas:getDrawFuncForID
api.description: Get a drawing function for a given id to avoid padding around the atlas and the id around, and just pass a function instead.

name: AppleCake
author: EngineerSmith
description: Profiling tool with detailed tools and thread support.

api.name: beginSession
api.description: Starts the profiling session by opening the mentioned file, and names the process with the 2nd argument
api.example:
AppleCake.beginSession() -- Creates profile.json in save directory, using the filesystem identity as the processes name
AppleCake.beginSession("profile-server.json", "game-server")

api.name: endSession
api.description: Close the current session and wait for write thread to rejoin this thread.

api.name: enable
api.description:
Enable or disable profiling tools in certain parts of the code.
See AppleCake own docs for more details and examples.
api.example:
AppleCake.enable("all")
AppleCake.enable("none")
appleCake.enable("profile") -- only enable profiles
appleCake.enable("mark") -- only enable marks
appleCake.enable("counter") -- only enable counters

api.name: profile
api.description: Profile a section of code over time.
api.example:
local profile
function love.update(dt)
  profile = AppleCake.profile("update", {deltaTime=dt}, profile)
  -- code
  profile:stop()
end

api.name: profileFunc
api.description: Profile a function, this is similar to AppleCake.profile but generates the profile name for you.
api.example:
local profile
function love.update(dt)
  profile = AppleCake.profileFunc({deltaTime=dt}, profile)
  -- code
  profile:stop()
end

api.name: profile:stop
api.description: Stop the mentioned profile.

api.name: stopProfile
api.description: Stop the mentioned profile. It's usually quicker to call profile:stop(), which calls the same function

api.name: mark
api.description: Mark a timeless event. Scope changes the notice-able size of the mark on the viewer. "p" for process, "t" for thread.

api.name: counter
api.description: Track a variables change overtime with a bar graph.
api.example:
local counter
function love.update(dt)
  counter = AppleCake.counter("Memory", {memory=collectgarbage("count")}, counter)
end

api.name: countMemory
api.description: Record the current memory usage. By default this is in "kilobyte"; other options include "megabyte" and "byte"
name: setName
description: Set the name for the process and the current thread

name: setThreadName
description: Set the name for the current thread
name: AppleCake.jprof.push
description: Push a profile to the current stack.
name: AppleCake.jprof.pop
description: Pop the current profile from the stack. Use the name argument to ensure it is the correct profile
name: AppleCake.jprof.popAll
description: Pop all on the current stack.
name: AppleCake.jprof.write
description: Different to jprof due to AppleCake's workflow. Will close the current file and open a new file with the give filename. Defaults to "profile.json"
name: AppleCake.jprof.enabled
description: Enable or disable profiles after this point.
name: AppleCake.jprof.connect
description: This function isn't supported in AppleCake
name: AppleCake.jprof.netFlush
description: This function isn't supported in AppleCake
name: AppleCake.jprof.START
description: Same function as AppleCake.beginSession, but added to the jprof table.
name: AppleCake.jprof.COUNTMEMORY
description: Same funtion as AppleCake.countMemory, but added to the jprof table.
